item.title: From the vaults: Multiculturalism and Animal Ethics
item.description: What should we do when cultural or religious traditions appear to conflict with current ideas about animal welfare? In a world where animal rights are often used as a cover for racism, David Grumett, Angie Pepper, and Varun Uberoi discuss how to advocate for animals without reinstating cultural imperialism.
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)
item.itunes:subtitle: What should we do when cultural or religious traditions appear to conflict with current ideas about animal welfare? item.itunes:summary: What should we do when cultural or religious traditions appear to conflict with current ideas about animal welfare? item.title: From the vaults: Affirmative Action
item.description: In this episode, philosopher Elizabeth Anderson and Runnymede Trust Director Omar Khan discuss affirmative action. What is it? Why is it so controversial?
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)
item.itunes:subtitle: In this episode, philosopher Elizabeth Anderson and Runnymede Trust Director Omar Khan discuss affirmative action. What is it? Why is it so controversial?
item.itunes:author: Forum for Philosophy
item.itunes:summary: In this episode, philosopher Elizabeth Anderson and Runnymede Trust Director Omar Khan discuss affirmative action. What is it? Why is it so controversial?

item.title: From the vaults: Prejudice
item.description: Are we more or less prejudiced than at other points in history? And is prejudice always wrong, or even avoidable? If it is avoidable, how can this be achieved? Marco Cinnirella, Katharine Jenkins, Joe Mulhall, and Amir Saeed discuss.
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)
item.itunes:subtitle: Are we more or less prejudiced than at other points in history? And is prejudice always wrong, or even avoidable? If it is avoidable, how can this be achieved? Marco Cinnirella, Katharine Jenkins, Joe Mulhall, and Amir Saeed discuss.
item.itunes:author: Forum for Philosophy
item.itunes:summary: Are we more or less prejudiced than at other points in history? And is prejudice always wrong, or even avoidable? If it is avoidable, how can this be achieved? Marco Cinnirella, Katharine Jenkins, Joe Mulhall, and Amir Saeed discuss.

item.title: From the Vaults: Frantz Fanon and Political Activism
item.description: Michael Burns, Madhu Krishnan and John Narayan explore what Fanon's work can teach us about the contemporary world.
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)
item.itunes:subtitle: Michael Burns, Madhu Krishnan and John Narayan explore what Fanon's work can teach us about the contemporary world.

item.title: From the vault: The Philosophy of Race
item.description: In this episode, Kwame Anthony Appiah, Priyamvada Gopal, and Nasar Meer consider what we understand by race, and the relationships between race, inequality, and prejudice.
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)
item.itunes:subtitle: In this episode, Kwame Anthony Appiah, Priyamvada Gopal, and Nasar Meer consider what we understand by race, and the relationships between race, inequality, and prejudice.

item.title: From the vaults: Is Political Violence Ever Justified?
item.description: Are some types of political violence more rational, ethical, or justifiable than others? Maeve Cooke and Kimberley Hutchings discuss.
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)
item.itunes:subtitle: Are some types of political violence more rational, ethical, or justifiable than others? Maeve Cooke and Kimberley Hutchings discuss.

item.title: From the vaults: The Politics of Memorials
item.description: Some people and events are remembered by communities, others forgotten. Who and what ought to be remembered? Should some memorials be removed? And who should decide? Michelle Codrington-Rogers, Margaret O'Callaghan, and Rahul Rao explore these questions and more.
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)
item.itunes:subtitle: Some people and events are remembered by communities, others forgotten. Who and what ought to be remembered? Should some memorials be removed? And who should decide? Michelle Codrington-Rogers, Margaret O'Callaghan, and Rahul Rao explore these questions and more.

item.itunes:summary: Some people and events are remembered by communities, others forgotten. Who and what ought to be remembered? Should some memorials be removed? And who should decide? Michelle Codrington-Rogers, Margaret O'Callaghan, and Rahul Rao explore these questions and more.

item.title: From the vault: What Are Prisons For?
item.description: Christopher Bennett, Kimberley Brownlee, and Andrew Neilson discuss the arguments against the use of imprisonment as a dominant form of punishment. Why do they so often fall on deaf ears?
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)
item.itunes:subtitle: Christopher Bennett, Kimberley Brownlee, and Andrew Neilson discuss the arguments against the use of imprisonment as a dominant form of punishment. Why do they so often fall on deaf ears?
item.itunes:author: Forum for Philosophy
item.itunes:summary: Christopher Bennett, Kimberley Brownlee, and Andrew Neilson discuss the arguments against the use of imprisonment as a dominant form of punishment. Why do they so often fall on deaf ears?

item.title: From the vaults: Immigration Detention
item.description: Should the state be allowed indefinitely detain people who have committed no crime? What does detention tell us about the ethics of immigration control? In this episode, Mishka, Mary Bosworth, and Matthew Gibney take a closer look at immigration detention.
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)
item.itunes:subtitle: Should the state be allowed indefinitely detain people who have committed no crime? What does detention tell us about the ethics of immigration control? In this episode, Mishka, Mary Bosworth, and Matthew Gibney take a closer look at immigration detention.
item.itunes:author: Forum for Philosophy
item.itunes:summary: Should the state be allowed indefinitely detain people who have committed no crime? What does detention tell us about the ethics of immigration control? In this episode, Mishka, Mary Bosworth, and Matthew Gibney take a closer look at immigration detention.

item.title: From the vaults: Who Is a Refugee?
item.description: Some people crossing borders are called refugees while others are not. But who is a refugee? What precisely is the relationship between migration and seeking refuge? Can we justify the distinction between refugees, migrants, and displaced people? Ahmad Al-Rashid, Phillip Cole, and Elspeth Guild discuss whether current legal definitions are need of modification, and if so, what should be altered and why.
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)
item.itunes:subtitle: Some people crossing borders are called refugees while others are not. But who is a refugee? What precisely is the relationship between migration and seeking refuge? Can we justify the distinction between refugees, migrants, and displaced people? Ahmad Al-Rashid, Phillip Cole, and Elspeth Guild discuss whether current legal definitions are need of modification, and if so, what should be altered and why.
item.itunes:author: Forum for Philosophy
item.itunes:summary: Some people crossing borders are called refugees while others are not. But who is a refugee? What precisely is the relationship between migration and seeking refuge? Can we justify the distinction between refugees, migrants, and displaced people? Ahmad Al-Rashid, Phillip Cole, and Elspeth Guild discuss whether current legal definitions are need of modification, and if so, what should be altered and why.

item.title: From the vaults: A Right to Be an Independent State?
item.description: John Breuilly and Cara Nine on what gives a territory the right to become an independent country, and under what conditions can or should a state prevent it from doing so.
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)
item.itunes:subtitle: John Breuilly and Cara Nine on what gives a territory the right to become an independent country, and under what conditions can or should a state prevent it from doing so.

item.itunes:summary: John Breuilly and Cara Nine on what gives a territory the right to become an independent country, and under what conditions can or should a state prevent it from doing so.

item.title: From the vaults: Sovereignty
item.description: In this episode, Serena Ferente, Carmen Pavel and David Runciman explore 'sovereignty' and ask whether it is still a useful concept in the twenty-first century.
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)
item.itunes:subtitle: In this episode, Serena Ferente, Carmen Pavel and David Runciman explore 'sovereignty' and ask whether it is still a useful concept in the twenty-first century.

item.itunes:summary: In this episode, Serena Ferente, Carmen Pavel and David Runciman explore 'sovereignty' and ask whether it is still a useful concept in the twenty-first century.

item.title: From the vault: A Right to Migrate?
item.description: Most would agree that we have a right to leave our country of origin. But since this usually means arriving in another, do we also have a right to immigrate? Chris Bertram, Emily Dugan, Matthew Gibney, and Madeleine Sumption discuss these and related questions.
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)
item.itunes:subtitle: Most would agree that we have a right to leave our country of origin. But since this usually means arriving in another, do we also have a right to immigrate? Chris Bertram, Emily Dugan, Matthew Gibney, and Madeleine Sumption discuss these and related questions.
item.itunes:author: Forum for Philosophy
item.itunes:summary: Most would agree that we have a right to leave our country of origin. But since this usually means arriving in another, do we also have a right to immigrate? Chris Bertram, Emily Dugan, Matthew Gibney, and Madeleine Sumption discuss these and related questions.

item.title: From the vaults: Being Alone
item.description: In this episode, John Burnside, Barbara Taylor, and James Warren explore the idea of loneliness and solitude, in philosophy, art and politics, as well as in our own lives.
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)
item.itunes:subtitle: In this episode, John Burnside, Barbara Taylor, and James Warren explore the idea of loneliness and solitude, in philosophy, art and politics, as well as in our own lives.

item.title: From the vaults: Immortality
item.description: Stephen Cave and John Gray ponder immortality. Might science provide the route to everlasting life? Should we even want it to? And is the will to live forever a blessing or a curse?
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)

item.title: From the vaults: Feminism
item.description: What is the future for feminism? How does feminism interact with concerns about other forms of oppression, such as those based on race and class?
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)
item.itunes:subtitle: What is the future for feminism? How does feminism interact with concerns about other forms of oppression, such as those based on race and class?

item.description: What makes a life good? Is the good life a happy life? We address the meaning and significance of the ‘good life’ today.

item.title: From the vaults: Reason and Rhetoric
item.description: Political discussion often turns ugly. John Crace, Catarina Dutilh Novaes, William Outhwaite, and Jo Phillips explore whether spin and negative campaigning are an unavoidable, even essential, feature of political life.

item.title: From the vaults: On the Unreasonable Effectiveness of Mathematics in Science
item.description: Eleanor Knox, Bryan Roberts, and Mairi Sakellariadou discuss why is it that abstract pieces of mathematics, like imaginary numbers, often later turn out to be surprisingly effective in describing the natural world

item.description: How seriously should we take philosophical worries about mathematics? And should mathematical results ever force our philosophical hands? Nicholas Bingham, Tim Button, Mary Leng, and Adam Ostaszewski on the trouble with numbers.

item.title: From the vaults: Prejudice
item.description: are we more or less prejudiced than at other points in our history? And is prejudice always wrong, or even avoidable? If it is avoidable, how can this be achieved? We put these questions to Marco Cinnirella, Katharine Jenkins, Joe Mulhall, and Amir Saeed.
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)

item.title: From the vaults: Unrequited Love
item.description: Ulrika Carlsson, Stephen Grosz, and Erin Plunkett explore responses to unrequited love in philosophy, psychoanalysis and art. Should we mourn or celebrate it? What can it teach us about ourselves?
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)

item.title: From the vaults: Shame
item.description: Shame is often depicted as playing only a negative role, but might it have have an important, positive role, for individuals and societies? Phil Hutchinson, Vasudevi Reddy, and Jonathan Webber on the nature and development of shame.
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)
item.itunes:subtitle: Shame is often depicted as playing only a negative role, but might it have have an important, positive role, for individuals and societies? Phil Hutchinson, Vasudevi Reddy, and Jonathan Webber on the nature and development of shame.

item.title: From the vaults: Hypocrisy
item.description: Why do we tend to judge hypocrites more harshly than those whose actions, however bad, appear consistent with their beliefs? Joanna Burch-Brown, Jussi Suikkanen, and Demetris Tillyris discuss whether hypocrisy is a moral dead-end or a step on the path to better behaviour.
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)

item.title: From the vaults: Guilt
item.description: Is guilt one emotion or many? What is the relationship between different kinds of guilt? Robert Eaglestone and Edward Harcourt on guilt.

item.title: From the vaults: Aristotle
item.description: Aristotle may be well known, but is he still relevant? Almost two and a half millennia on, what can he tell us about modern life? Joachim Aufderheide, Sophie Grace Chappell, and Sophia Connell on contemporary lessons from Aristotle.
item.dc:creator: philosophy-forum@lse.ac.uk (Forum for Philosophy)

item.description: Ian McBride, Katherine O'Donnell, and Tom Stoneham explore the Irish Enlightenment and its turbulent politics. Is something distinctively Irish about this group of thinkers?

item.description: Sarah Bakewell, Andy Martin, and Stella Sandford on the allure of existentialism. How can it be, at once, avidly consumed by modern audiences and unapologetically esoteric?

item.title: From the vaults: Darwin
item.description: Tim Lewens/ David Papineau    Listen to the podcast here   Darwin was primarily a biologist rather than a philosopher, but his work has had huge significance for how philosophers think about many of philosophy’s central problems. item.title: From the vaults: Pragmatism

item.title: From the vaults: Can We Learn from Suffering?
item.description: Danielle Sands/ Anatasia Scrutton/ Tom Stern   Listen to the recording here   The ‘most depressing lesson’ of suffering, Slavoj Žižek writes, is that ‘there is nothing to be learned from it’. Is Žižek’s bleak view convincing, or is there evidence to suggest that suffering can educate or even improve us? item.title: From the vaults: Thinking about Children’s Mental Health
item.description: Rachel Cooper/ Eileen Munro/ Emily Simonoff   Listen to the recording here   The classification, identification, and treatment of mental illnesses in children raises particular challenges. For example, what are the appropriate criteria for diagnosing children with a mental disorder? How can we avoid the risk of stigmatisation that some children and their families experience? … Continued
